channel.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
channel.description:
I'm trying to print out information contained between symbols ':' and ';'
name: Java;
I want "Java" printed out How would I go about doing that?

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Honestly, I feel bad here that StringTokenizer was only mentioned once… You really should use StringTokenizer over a BufferedReader that goes through looking for tokens. Why? Because that’s exactly what StringTokenizer is designed to do. You could go to a distance of using regular expressions which RSCShadow pointed out (but obviously in Java in this situation) and use capture groups to extract your information. With a loop, it becomes dynamic, as well. I would recommend you use StringTokenizer over regex, though. If your format starts becoming more complicated and has specific rules (like an integer must go here, etc.), then you can move onto regular expressions. If your format becomes extremely complex, look into implementing a parser like JavaCC.

Read full topic
item.source: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader

Edit: Okay I see now. Alright then. Thank you.

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“hadesflames, post:15, topic:534248”]Which is meaningless because it was clear the user wasn’t going to be inputting anything…Stop arguing with me, the point is in this specific case, there was no need or reason to be so scrutinous with the code.[/quote][quote=“ravekitty, post:1, topic:534248”]I’m trying to print out information contained between symbols ‘:’ and ‘;’

name: Java;

I want “Java” printed out

How would I go about doing that?[/quote]
Nowhere in this did he say that the user wasn’t going to be inputting anything… I’m not arguing with you, I’m saying you didn’t account for this; that is a fact and you’re too arrogant to accept it or notice the possible flaw.

Read full topic

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“hadesflames, post:12, topic:534248”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=653044.msg4376025#msg4376025 date=1382062754]
He didn’t specify the exact parameters for the argument, he gave an example. If you don’t think there’s a difference then you obviously haven’t done much programming on your own time.
Your code separates it by semicolons, hades, that is the flaw with it. It doesn’t find the first semicolon and go from there, it separates the entire string by the semicolons. It will be flawed if the parameter had a semicolon.
[/quote]

facepalm

The semicolons are used to END the string, not further separation. Since he provided no further information than his example, it is clear that he’s implying the colons separate the strings, and semi-colons end the string. There is nothing wrong with my code in terms of the problem brought up by the OP. If it turns out that my code does not work for some case in his input, then it is HIS fault for not being more clear and specific about how input should look. Furthermore, look at the first response, the OP said this code worked. This is even further indication that the semicolons do nothing more than END the string. My code is just basically a better way of doing the same thing.[/quote]
I never said it was bad, you just didn’t account for any variety in string type. If a user were to be the one inputting the string, this code could easily be manipulated and hacked… That’s the only reason I’m saying any of this

Read full topic

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[code]String items[] = string.split(’;’);
HashMap<String, String> arrayItems = new HashMap<String, String>();

for (String item : items) {
String[] pieces = item.split(’:’);
arrayItems.put(pieces[0], pieces[1]);
System.out.print(pieces[1]); // if the argument was “name: Java;”, “Java” would be printed.
}[/code]
Ofc this is missing some of the “little things”, but that’s just practice for you!

Read full topic

Your code separates it by semicolons, hades, that is the flaw with it. It doesn’t find the first semicolon and go from there, it separates the entire string by the semicolons. It will be flawed if the parameter had a semicolon.

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @hadesflames hadesflames
item.description:
@hadesflames wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:7, topic:534248”][quote author=hadesflames link=topic=653044.msg4375973#msg4375973 date=1382056673]
Here’s a better way:

public static String format(String raw){ String split[] = raw.split(":"); if(split.length < 2) return ""; String formatted = split[1].trim(); return formatted.substring(0, formatted.length() - 1); }
[/quote]
What if the string happened to be, "ro:fl"
Not saying it’s likely, and not saying it’s even possible (he never specified what gives the input), but yours would screw up. :p[/quote]

It’s implied that there will be a semi-colon at the end of each string, so no, my code wouldn’t “mess up.”

Read full topic
item.source: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:7, topic:534248”][quote author=hadesflames link=topic=653044.msg4375973#msg4375973 date=1382056673]
Here’s a better way:

public static String format(String raw){ String split[] = raw.split(":"); if(split.length < 2) return ""; String formatted = split[1].trim(); return formatted.substring(0, formatted.length() - 1); }
[/quote]
What if the string happened to be, "ro:fl"
Not saying it’s likely, and not saying it’s even possible (he never specified what gives the input), but yours would screw up. :p[/quote]

He did specify.

[code=java]
public static void main(String[] args) {
String input = “name: Java;”;

	System.out.println(format(input));
}

private static String format(String input) {
	return input.substring(input.indexOf(':') + 2, input.indexOf(';'));
}[/code]

Why the complexity for something so simple?

Edit: prettier code

Read full topic

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @ravekitty ravekitty
item.description:
@ravekitty wrote:

[quote=“Kiryn, post:2, topic:534248”][quote author=ravekitty link=topic=653044.msg4375886#msg4375886 date=1382047748]
I’m trying to print out information contained between symbols ‘:’ and ‘;’

name: Java;

I want “Java” printed out

How would I go about doing that?
[/quote]

is this what you mean?

[code] public String example(String str)
{
for(int i = 0; i < str.length(); i++)
{

		if(str.charAt(i) == ':')
		{
			str = str.substring(i+2);
			str = str.replaceAll(";", "");
		}
	}
	return str;
}[/code]

How to use: public static void main(String[] args) { String str = "name: Java;"; Example m = new Example(); System.out.println(m.example(str)); }

prints: Java[/quote]

Yes, perfect, thank you very much

Read full topic
item.source: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader

item.title: Grabbing certain information using buffered reader
item.dc:creator: @Kiryn Kiryn
item.description:
@Kiryn wrote:

[quote=“ravekitty, post:1, topic:534248”]I’m trying to print out information contained between symbols ‘:’ and ‘;’

name: Java;

I want “Java” printed out

How would I go about doing that?[/quote]

is this what you mean?

[code] public String example(String str)
{
for(int i = 0; i < str.length(); i++)
{

		if(str.charAt(i) == ':')
		{
			str = str.substring(i+2);
			str = str.replaceAll(";", "");
		}
	}
	return str;
}[/code]

How to use: public static void main(String[] args) { String str = "name: Java;"; Example m = new Example(); System.out.println(m.example(str)); }

prints: Java
